quiz.title: Unit 5: Work & Energy (Quiz 1)
quiz.subtitle: Fundamentals of Work, Energy and Mechanical Power (50 Questions)
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which of the following quantities is a scalar?
questions.explanation: Work has magnitude only and no direction, hence it is a scalar quantity.

questions.question: When a force acts on a body and there is no displacement, the work done is:
questions.explanation: Work is given by W = F × d × cosθ. If displacement d = 0, then W = 0.

questions.question: A force of 20 N moves an object 5 m in the direction of the force. Work done is:
The SI unit of energy is:
questions.explanation: The Joule (J) is the SI unit for both work and energy.

questions.question: A boy lifts a 10 kg box vertically through 2 m. The work done is approximately:
When work is done on a system, energy of the system:
questions.explanation: Positive work adds energy to the system, increasing its energy.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a form of mechanical energy?
questions.explanation: Heat energy is a form of thermal, not mechanical, energy.

questions.question: A 5 kg object moving at 4 m/s has kinetic energy:
Doubling the speed of an object increases its kinetic energy by:
questions.explanation: KE ∝ v², so doubling v makes KE four times larger.

questions.question: The potential energy of a 2 kg body at a height of 10 m is:
Which of the following statements about work and energy is correct?
options: Work is the rate of energy change
Work and energy have the same unit
Energy is always greater than work
questions.explanation: Both work and energy are measured in Joules.

questions.question: If the angle between force and displacement is 90°, the work done is:
questions.explanation: W = Fd cosθ; when θ = 90°, cos90° = 0 → W = 0.

questions.question: Which of these has maximum potential energy?
options: A book on a high shelf
questions.explanation: A book on a high shelf has gravitational potential energy due to its elevated position.

questions.question: If power is the rate of doing work, then its SI unit is:
questions.explanation: 1 Watt = 1 Joule per second.

questions.question: A machine does 600 J of work in 20 s. Power developed is:
A man carries a 15 kg load 20 m horizontally at constant speed. Work done against gravity is:
questions.explanation: No vertical displacement means no work against gravity.

questions.question: The work done by friction on a moving body is usually:
questions.explanation: Friction opposes motion; hence work done by it is negative.

questions.question: The energy possessed by a stretched rubber band is:
questions.explanation: It stores energy due to change in shape — elastic potential energy.

questions.question: Work done against friction is converted into:
questions.explanation: Work against friction produces heat due to surface resistance.

questions.question: A 60 W bulb consumes 60 J of energy in:
questions.explanation: Power = Energy / time → time = 60/60 = 1 s.

questions.question: A car engine does 30,000 J of work in 10 s. Its power is:
When a body is raised through a height, the work done is stored as:
questions.explanation: Work done lifting a body becomes gravitational potential energy.

questions.question: If a machine has 80% efficiency, it means:
questions.explanation: Efficiency = Useful work / Input work × 100%; 20% is lost as heat or friction.

questions.question: The work-energy theorem states that:
options: Work done equals change in kinetic energy
Work done equals change in potential energy only
Power equals energy per unit area
questions.explanation: According to the theorem, W = ΔKE.

questions.question: Which of the following quantities can be negative?
questions.explanation: Work can be negative when force opposes displacement.

questions.question: A man pushes a wall with 100 N of force, but the wall does not move. The work done is:
questions.explanation: No displacement occurs, so work done is zero despite applied force.

questions.question: If a 200 N force acts through 5 m at 60° to displacement, work done is:
A motor raises a 500 kg load vertically through 10 m in 25 s. The power output is:
Which form of energy is associated with motion?
questions.explanation: Kinetic energy is the energy of motion, given by ½mv².

questions.question: Work done per unit time is known as:
questions.explanation: Power = Work / time.

questions.question: If 150 J of work is done in 5 seconds, the power developed is:
The unit of power equivalent to one million watts is:
questions.explanation: 1 Megawatt (MW) = 10⁶ W.

questions.question: When is work said to be negative?
options: Force and displacement are in same direction
questions.explanation: Work is negative when force acts opposite to the displacement.

questions.question: A hammer strikes a nail and drives it into wood. The type of energy conversion is:
questions.explanation: Kinetic energy of hammer converts to heat, sound, and work driving the nail.

questions.question: The energy stored in a compressed spring is:
questions.explanation: Deformation stores elastic potential energy.

questions.question: A 1000 W motor lifts a 50 kg load. How high can it lift it in 10 s? (g = 9.8 m/s²)
In which situation is work done by gravity zero?
questions.explanation: Gravity does no work when displacement is perpendicular to its direction.

questions.question: Which statement best defines the joule?
options: Work done by 1 N through 1 m
questions.explanation: 1 Joule = 1 Newton × 1 meter (work done by unit force through unit distance).

questions.question: A 2 kg mass is dropped from 5 m. What is its kinetic energy just before hitting the ground?
questions.explanation: PE lost = KE gained = mgh = 2×9.8×5 = 98 J.

questions.question: Mechanical energy of a body is the sum of:
questions.explanation: Mechanical energy = KE + PE.

questions.question: When a body falls freely, its potential energy:
questions.explanation: As height decreases, potential energy is converted into kinetic energy.

questions.question: If a machine has an efficiency of 100%, it means:
questions.explanation: 100% efficiency means all input energy is converted to useful output — no loss.

questions.question: When a constant force acts at right angles to displacement, the work done is:
questions.explanation: W = Fd cosθ; if θ = 90°, cosθ = 0, so W = 0.

questions.question: Which of these situations involves negative work?
questions.explanation: Braking opposes motion, so the work done by friction is negative.

questions.question: A 0.5 kg ball is thrown upward with 20 J of kinetic energy. Maximum height reached is:
When an object falls freely, total mechanical energy:
questions.explanation: In absence of air resistance, total mechanical energy (KE + PE) is conserved.

questions.question: The power of an engine is 2 kW. In 5 seconds, it does work of:
Which of these is not a unit of work?
questions.explanation: Watt-second per second simplifies to watt, which is a unit of power, not work.

questions.question: A weightlifter lifts 100 kg to a height of 2 m. Work done is:
If energy is transferred at a faster rate, the power output is:
questions.explanation: Power ∝ rate of energy transfer; faster transfer means higher power.

scoreMessages.90: Outstanding! You've demonstrated mastery of work and energy relationships.
scoreMessages.70: Good job! You understand the core concepts; review applications of power.
scoreMessages.50: Fair performance. Strengthen understanding of energy conversion and efficiency.
scoreMessages.0: Don't give up! Review force, displacement, and basic work-energy relations.
